math_problem:
Solve in integers the equation
\[ x^2+xy+y^2 = \left(\frac{x+y}{3}+1\right)^3. \] Instead of finding all integer solutions $(x, y)$, simply find $k$, the smallest positive value of $y + 20$ among all integer solutions $(x, y)$. Solve in the set of real numbers the equation \[ k x^{k} - [x] = k, \] where $ [x]$ denotes the integer part of $ x.$
